Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Situation2: They participate in a national continuing education program to maintain licensure and expertise in the latest treatments.
Story: I glanced at my phone, a message from Alex lighting up the screen: “Which night should we do dinner this week? I’m free any evening!” My heart fluttered. We’d both been so busy, and finally, we had a stretch of evenings to ourselves. I wanted to pick the perfect night, to make it special, to show him how much I cared. But as I opened my calendar, my stomach tightened. The national continuing education program for pharmacists was running all week, with live webinars every evening—sessions I needed to attend to keep my license and stay sharp for my patients. My manager had stressed how important it was to keep up, and I knew missing them would mean falling behind. I could feel the weight of both worlds pressing in: Alex’s hopeful anticipation, the professional responsibility I couldn’t ignore. I wanted to be the girlfriend who made time, who was present and loving. I also needed to be the pharmacist who never let her knowledge slip. My mind raced, torn between the warmth of a dinner date and the cold necessity of professional growth, unsure which part of me should come first.
